block.p: Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a winged preschooler, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious Maya, who looks like a winged preschooler, to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $15; $7 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''ARABIAN NIGHTS.'' Youngsters won't have to jump aboard a magic carpet and ride to an exotic desert kingdom to hear these stories, presented by the Young Vic Theater Company on an enchanted circle of sand. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan. Fridays and Thursdays at 7; Wednesday at 7 p.m.; Saturdays at 1 and 7 p.m.; Sundays at noon and 6 p.m. Through Oct. 22. Tickets: $10, $20 and $25. Reservations: (212) 239-6200.

PAPAGENO PUPPET THEATER presents two productions with Susan Delery Whedon, a puppeteer and singer: ''Hansel and Gretel,'' the fairy tale, with music by Humperdinck (at 11:30 a.m.) and ''Puff, the Magic Dragon,'' with music by Peter, Paul and Mary (2:30 p.m.). Saturdays and Sundays through Oct. 29 at 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations: (212) 874-3297.

SCHMOOZY TOGETHERNESS, an hourlong musical from Manhattan Theater Source (''Kingdom of the Sun''), in which the heroine, Schmoozy, ventures into a magical meta-forest. Although theatergoers under 10 may not understand the puns in Sam Forman's book and lyrics, they will enjoy seeing grown-ups act silly. Sunday and Oct. 22 at 1 p.m. at Manhattan Theater Source, 177 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.

''THE SWINEHERD,'' the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale about a materialistic princess, adapted by Morna Murphy Martell. Vital Children's Theater, third floor, 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Saturdays through Nov. 4 at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 592-4508.
Events

''BEAUTY AND THE BEAST.'' Queens Theater in the Park's series for children presents the fairy tale performed by the Ballet for Young Audiences, with narration, music and elaborate costumes, tomorrow at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. at Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, off Exit 9E of the Grand Central Parkway, near Shea Stadium. Tickets: $8; $6 for members; $5 for members when ordering 4 or more. Information: (718) 760-0064.

''CHILDREN'S THEATER-HISTORY WORKSHOPS: FRANCES ELLEN WATKINS HARPER.'' Children 7 to 12 will learn about this 19th-century African-American political activist, poet and novelist in a workshop series over four consecutive Saturdays. The first session is tomorrow, from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Morris-Jumel Mansion (the only remaining house in Manhattan built before the Revolution), 65 Jumel Terrace, between 160th and 162d Streets, one block east of St. Nicholas Avenue, Washington Heights. Participants will also create artworks and prepare a staged reading of an original drama. Free. Advance registration is required. Take a bag lunch. Information: (212) 923-8008.

''GHOST SHIPS.'' Stories about ghosts and mystery ships, and a chance to create a spooky storybook and puppet to take home, will be part of a workshop tomorrow from noon to 2 p.m. at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Free with museum admission: $12; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 6 to 11, $6; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Information: (212) 245-0072.

''HARVEST TIME HANGINGS.'' A workshop on creating decorative wall hangings out of cones, pods, seed heads and grasses will take place tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at a workshop at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200, extension 213.

LATIN AMERICAN FESTIVAL. In celebration of Hispanic Heritage Month, activities tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the Queens Central Library, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica, Queens, include storytelling and puppet making, dance and music from many parts of Latin America. Crafts are at 1 and 3 (materials supplied, but are limited). Information: (718) 990-0767. Free.

''THE ORCHESTRA -- A HAPPY FAMILY.'' The Little Orchestra Society presents the first of the fall Lolli-Pops Concerts series, teaching children 3 to 5 about the basics of music. Bang the Lion, Bow the Panda, Buzz the Bee and Toot the Bird are among the cast of characters. The music includes Gershwin's ''Strike Up the Band,'' Herbert's ''March of the Toys'' and Tchaikovsky's ''Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy'' from ''The Nutcracker.'' Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. and noon; Sunday at 9:30 and 11 a.m., 1 and 2:30 p.m. Three-concert subscriptions are $96; single tickets are $35. Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan. Information: (212) 971-9500.

''THE PROMISE OF THE PARK,'' a walking tour revisiting 18th- and 19th-century Central Park on Sunday, beginning at noon at 100th Street and Central Park West, culminating in a performance. The tour will end at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street, where Theater-in-Motion will present the musical ''The Promise of the Park'' at 2 p.m., about Frederick Law Olmsted and the design of Central Park. The performance is free to participants in the tour, which is also free; all others, free with a suggested donation to the museum, $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. To register: (888) 573-7554.

''PUNCH VAN WINKLE,'' an old-fashioned puppet show popular with 19th-century audiences, who enjoyed the antics of the mischievous title character. Fred Greenspan, a puppeteer, presents an adaptation of the Washington Irving tale on Sunday at 1 and 2:30 p.m. at the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum and Garden (formerly the Abigail Adams Smith Museum), 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. Admission: $6; $4 for children and members. Space is limited; advance tickets advised. Information: (212) 838-6878.

RUSSIAN AMERICAN KIDS CIRCUS. Acrobatics, tightrope walking, juggling, clowning and hula hoop are part of the Family Folk and Fairy Tale series at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, between the West Side Highway and Greenwich Street, tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. Tickets: $13; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 346-8510.

''THOMAS OSHA PINNOCK: REGGAE BOOGIE TALK SHOW.'' The Jamaican performance artist and storyteller will invoke ritual drama, song chants and traditional Jamaican folklore, tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $10; $5 for children. Information: (212) 255-5793, extension 11.

''TWIGS AND THINGS.'' Youngsters can celebrate fall by exploring the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, in a workshop tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon. Participants will collect leaves and twigs to make rubbings, cards, mobiles and classification booklets. Fee: $5. Reservations: (212) 932-7347.

''WHAT TO DO FOR THE SCIENCE FAIR?'' The yearly problem will be made easier tomorrow from 10 a.m. to noon at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Experts in the field and the educator Clay Wollney, known as Mr. Discovery, will answer questions and offer suggestions about creating great science fair projects. Free, but preregistration required. Information: (718) 727-1135, extension 29.
Exhibitions

''AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART.'' Children's workshops are offered in conjunction with this show at the Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, on Sundays from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. through Dec. 17. This week's theme is ''Under Cover,'' focusing on weaving using colored paper. Admission: free for the museum; $1 materials charge for workshops. Information: (212) 595-9533.

''GOOD GRIEF!'' Charlie Brown and his creator, Charles M. Schulz, are the stars of the exhibition, in which families are invited to inhabit a life-size version of the ''Peanuts'' comic strip, which always offered lessons as well as laughs. Activities include video games, a psychotherapy session at Lucy's booth (cost: a nickel) or a crawl through the Great Pumpkin Patch. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free with museum admission: $6; $3 for the elderly; infants, free. Information: (212) 721-1234. In conjunction with the exhibition, the Film Society of Lincoln Center's Movies for Kids presents ''Good Grief! It's Charlie Brown in the Movies,'' beginning tomorrow and running through Oct. 22. Tomorrow and Sunday at 2 p.m., ''Race for Your Life, Charlie Brown'' (1977), in which the crew is off to summer camp, where Snoopy proves he's a formidable athlete. Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street. Tickets: $3. Information: (212) 875-5600.

''WILLIAM WEGMAN: CANES ECCLESIORUM'' (that's Latin for church dogs) is an exhibition of the photographer's famous pooches doing amazing humanlike things, created especially for the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, through Oct. 22. Free. Information: (212) 316-7540.
